boardgamehonor: 2009 Deutscher Lernspielpreis "3 years and up" Nominee
40960.description:
The sheep are on their way home, into their pen. The sky fills with clouds. There are often lovely things to be seen within their shapes.

A childrens game, somehow related to Pictionary. Instead of drawing with a pencil, the players in turn create images with the cloud tiles in the game. Either "draw" an item shown on a randomly drawn card; or (advanced rules) think up any item and draw it. The other players have to guess what the image is intended to show; if somebody manages to identify it correctly, both he and the active player gain one point.

Points are counted on a track, showing the way home for the sheep. First player to reach the barn wins.
40960.name: Wolkenbilder

40961.description:
A distant relative to Ingenious. There are 36 cards, each showing 1-3 gems in one of 4 different colors on each half. Players place these cards on the table, creating a pattern, and score points for matching gems on adjacant cards.

A player always has a hand of 3 cards. On his turn, he places one on the table, adjacent to at least one other card half. He now scores points for the number of gems matching the type/color of its neighbours. Placement and scoring are limited by the fact that there may never be more than 7 gems of one kind in a continuous row.

The game ends after 7 rounds. The player with the highest total points wins.

A enhanced edition from Wargames Club Publishing will be included a sand timer and the variant rules for more tight playing.
40961.name: Topas
boardgamepodcastepisode: BGB Volume 80 - Eurogames for the iPhone and iPad

boardgamehonor: 2009 Deutscher Lernspielpreis "6 years and up" Nominee
2009 Deutscher Spiele Preis Best Children's Game Winner
2009 Kinderspielexperten "5-to-9-year-olds" Nominee
2009 Spiel der Spiele Hit für Kinder Recommended
2010 Årets Spill Best Children's Game Nominee
2010 Lys Enfant Finalist
40962.description:
Story: The small, friendly vampire Victor is in his huge castle, and has misplaced many of his items. Fortunately, there are many mirrors that can be used to find these things without him having to move in all there rooms.

The game box with a coverage forms the castle. On each side, there are three windows. On stays open, the others are filled with images of the items to find - but visible only from the inside of the box. There are also 4 mirrors which can be stuck into the box (at 45 degree angles), which make it possible to see any of the items when looking through the one open window into the castle. There's also a door (used with the advanced rules) that can block the view.

Players in turn roll a die, and move Victor along a track at the top of the box. The space he's landing on show what item he now has to find. He may move up to 3 mirrors, then peek through the open window. If the wrong item shows up, it's the next players turn. But when the correct item is seen, he gains one blood token; afterward, that item and the open window switch places.

The other players may gain a blood token, too. After the active player has set up the mirrors, but before he looks to the window, they may predict whether the correct item shows up. If the guess right, the gain a drop.

The player that first a set number of blood tokens (depending on number of players) wins the game.
boardgameversion: German Edition with Deutscher Spielepreis & Preis der Wiener Spiele Akademie mark
40962.name: Burg der 1000 Spiegel

40964.description:
The game consists of a set of 81 tiles. Each is identified by a unique combination of four features: Form of the symbol, Colour of the symbol, Size of the symbol, Background colour. Each player starts with 10 of these tiles; goal is to get rid off them.

On his turn, the player may either swap one of his tiles; or he places a series of tiles on the table, where a pattern is formed the these tiles. Afterward, he always draws one tile; either from a small face-up supply, or from the bag.

A tile may only be placed adjacent to another one where 3 out of the 4 features are identical. In his turn, a player may place several tiles, but each tile after the first one has to be adjacent to the last tile he just played. There's a special award for placing a tile adjacent to at least two other tiles (within the placement rules).

The first player who has places his last tile wins the game.
40964.name: Unikato

40965.name: Martian Miners
40965.description:
Mars 2158. Since long this planet has been inhabited by humans, but only the light side. The
dark side has always been considered too dangerous, because of the plundering Martians
roaming these badlands. Two mining companies, however, have started a wager: who will be
the ultimate Martian Miner?

This piecepack game is a port of Catan. It uses:

Piecepack Game System
Icehouse Pieces

40966.name: In Love
40966.description:
Ask questions.. Talk about yourself and your relationship!

You have to solve tasks and answer questions in different categories like sensuality, relationship, knowledge, competition...

You will get to know your partner better and discover secret attributes of your partner.

Both players get a task-card (with four colors=fields of action) and a gift-card.
In the course of the game, you have to collect the four colors (= carry out some activities or answering questions). If you manage to do so before your partner does, you win the game and can convert your gift-card...

40967.name: Kunststück
40967.description:
From the Box:
"There is no heist too difficult for a true master thief. Not even breaking into art museums and stealing the most valuable paintings. Names like da Vinci, Rembrandt or Van Gogh are the pieces that dubious collectors want to have and these promise high earnings.
But beware: Other thieves also have their eyes on the best pieces. Only the one who is able to hide his spoil, dodges the raids from the police and is clever enough to sell the acquired art to the highest bidder will make the BIG business!"

40968.description:
ADAPT & ANNIHILATE! Change of an epic scale is sweeping the land. Makeda leads the Army of the Western Reaches to the Abyssal Fortress. Thagrosh undergoes a terrifying transformation as the power of Everblight increases. Krueger pursues a path of glory and stirs an ancient enmity. Madrak struggles with the curse of Rathrok even as he relies on the axe's strength to defend his people. And above all, the dragon threat grows ever stronger.

HORDES: Metamorphosis is the second expansion for the award-winning miniatures battle game set in the untamed lands of the Iron Kingdoms. Evolve your Monstrous Miniatures Combat with:

Three commanding new warlocks for each faction, including new EPIC characters
Powerful new war beasts for each faction, ready to rile
Dragoon rules introduced into HORDES for the first time
New painting and modeling guides for each faction




Expands

Hordes
40968.name: Hordes: Metamorphosis

40970.description:
Tenjiku Shogi (天竺将棋 tenjiku shōgi, or 天竺大将棋 tenjiku dai shōgi "exotic chess") is a large-board variant of shogi (Japanese chess). The game dates back to the 15th or 16th century and was based on the earlier chu shogi, which itself was based on dai shogi.

Tenjiku is played on a 16x16 un-checkered board.

Surely, Tenjiku Shogi is one of the deeper and most interesting large Shogi variant. While based on Chu Shogi (Middle Shogi), Tenjiku boasts a menagerie of wonderfully powerful pieces which make it a far more dynamic and fast paced game than the other large variants. It really stands out from the other great Shogi variants and deserves its name of "exotic". The exotic pieces include range jumpers which can jump over any number of pieces in order make a capture, and the Fire Demon which can "burn" all enemy pieces on the squares adjacent to where it lands!

Unlike in most other Shogi variants, tactics in Tenjiku are critical right from the first move of the game. Despite the large board, the power of the pieces can mean that careless play is rewarded with a lost game in only a few moves.
boardgameversion: The Shogi Association George Hodges edition
40970.name: Tenjiku Shogi

40971.description:
Dai-Dai shōgi (大大将棋 'huge chess') is a large board variant of shogi (Japanese chess). The game dates back to the 15th century and is based on the earlier Dai shogi. Apart from its size, the major difference is in the range of the pieces and the “promotion by capture” rule. It is the smallest board variant to use this rule.

Dai Dai Shogi is played on a 17x17 un-checkered board.

Dai Dai Shogi offers no less than 64 different types of piece, plus 4 more gotten after promotion, where Dai Shogi has only 36 types in total. Dai Dai Shogi has an asymmetrical starting set-up. The promotion by capture rules and the presence of the very powerful Hook Movers make Dai Dai Shogi a very different game from the smaller variants.
boardgameversion: The Shogi Association George Hodges edition
40971.name: Dai-Dai Shogi

40973.name: Basic Baroque
40973.description:
Basic Baroque is a miniature wargame. It uses the same simple but effective engine as Basic Impetus and expands it for the late Renaissance, eg. the period from about 1600 to 1700. So it can be used for the English Civil War and the Thirty Years War.

Armies are of very small size (about 8 to 12 bases, each of about 4 to 20 figures). It uses a "big bases" approach to give the players the option of making diorama style playing pieces.

40974.name: Superpoly
40974.description:
Monopoly-like game in Spanish which uses the names of famous Spanish streets for properties.

Nowadays, there are 4 brands in the superpoly family:

Superpoly Classic
Superpoly Deluxe
Euro Superpoly
Superpoly Deluxe Catalá

40976.name: Codes
40976.description:
In this piecepack game players try to make the code on the table match their own secret code. This is done by manipulation of the coins on the table and in an opaque bag.
The game uses Piecepack Game System.

40977.description:
Glonk Le Choc des Aliens is a small print (150 for the moment) game, self-published by a French designer. Rules are in French.

The game use the mechanics of the finger pitch to simulate a galactic war, each wood circular pawns representing a flying saucer. The mechanism of controlled pitch is the same developed in Pitch Bowl.

Each player control an armada and each armada consists of a spacial base and 8 to 12 flying saucers, with different powers :
- The Sinistrum Empire (malice, trickery),
- The United Worlds Organization (defense),
- The Zorgs (brutality),
- The Space Pirates (speed),
- The Little Grey Ones (technology,teleportation),
- The Invaders (number)
Each have their own powers to take the advantage.

The goal of the game is to destroy the other and reaching 7 points. You earn 1 point by killing an enemy flying saucer and 1 point for an enemy base.

For this, the flying saucers can project their opponents in the black hole or asteroids, use certain powers, boarding enemy ships or launch heroic assault against them.

The official blog ( http://glonk.sosblog.fr/) offer a campaign for two players based upon 1st trilogy of Star Wars : Pitch Wars.

Rules in English available.
40977.name: Glonk Le Choc des Aliens

40982.description:
Tai Shogi (泰将棋 tai shōgi or 無上泰将棋 mujō tai shōgi "grand chess", renamed from 無上大将棋 mujō dai shōgi "supreme chess" to avoid confusion with 大将棋 dai shōgi) is a large-board variant of Shogi (Japanese chess). The game dates to the 15th century and is based on earlier large board shogi games. Before the discovery of Taikyoku Shogi in 1997, Tai Shogi was believed to be the largest playable chess variant, if not board game, ever. One game may be played over several long sessions and require each player to make over a thousand moves. It was never a popular game; indeed, a single production of half a dozen game sets in the early 17th century was a notable event.

Like other large-board variants, but unlike standard Shogi, the game is played without drops, and uses a promotion-by-capture rule.

Tai Shogi is a gargantuan of a game both in terms of strategy and playing time. A serious game of Tai will require several long sessions to complete and may need over 1000 -moves per player. The game is simply too big to be played strategically, and therefore the game typically proceeds as a series of local skirmishes as both players try to develop their pieces and improve their position. Flat out rapid play will typically take at least three days (takes an hour or so to setup!).

While most of the 101 different pieces in Tai Shogi are also found in other variants, one unique feature of Tai is the presence right from the beginning of the game of the all powerful Emperors.

Tai Shogi is played on a board of 25 x 25 squares and each player has 177 pieces (including 25 pawns) ! A unique feature of Tai Shogi is the presence right from the start of the game of the all powerful Emperors. The Emperor has the greatest power of any piece in any of the Shogi variants as it may move in one turn to almost any square on the board, jumping over any number of pieces of either side in the process.

While you might think that the power of the Emperors would have a great impact on the course of the game, their powers tend to offset each other. It should be noted that any otherwise unprotected piece is always protected by its own Emperor.
boardgameversion: The Shogi Association George Hodges edition
40982.name: Tai Shogi

40983.name: Gefira
40983.description:
From the back of the box:

Lead your people to the other side!

Gefira...the only way out of the wretched jungle. Guide your explorers across a dangerous and unstable hanging bridge in a race of life and death. Your opponent will try to boycott, slow and outsmart you. You will need a sound strategy and use all of your wits to succeed in your mission!

But beware... snakes, strong winds, floods and more will cross your path on a bridge already half in ruins!

Overview:

Players need to escape the jungle by crossing a bridge. Crossing is made more strategic and difficult by flipping and replacing parts of the bridge based on cards that are drafted that can trigger events - both negative and positive.

40984.name: To The Pole With Shackleton
40984.description: This game, from the famous shop 'Hamleys Of London' was produced around Christmas time in 1910 and is about Ernest Shackleton's near miss attempt to reach the South Pole during that year. (He eventually succeeds in 1914-1916). I know little about the game except that I did see an artist's rendition of the game being played in the book "SAFE RETURN DOUBTFUL - The Heroic Age of Polar Exploration" written by John Maxtone-Graham. The game is about racing sleighs to the south pole and uses pencils to map out the route. From page 259 of the book. "The game was played on a large circular papier-mache board, painted white and grooved with concentric ridges of miniature sastrugi (SASTRUGI = Wind eroded snow, which often looks rough, like frozen waves. Usually found on windward slopes). Each player assumed the identity of a famous explorer and, equipped with special magnetic pencils, coaxed miniature sledges through the maze of tracks toward the central pole, False leads led to dead ends, and any player thus stymied could extricate his sled only by using a magnet of reversed polarity marked "Dr. Cook""

40985.name: Knuckle Knipper
40985.description:
Knuckle Knipper is a game of tension, memory, and frustration.

Each plastic 'Knipper' can be depressed from two sides. Press one side and 'Ouch' - it snaps shut around your finger. Press the other side and it refuses to snap.

Playing this game needs 'steady nerves', a good memory, and an element of bluff. Players make their way from the centre of the board to their home corner by throwing the dice. The route is of their choosing.

Each time a player stops he must depress the side of the Knuckle Knipper nearest his spot. If it's safe, he may rest easy - if it 'snaps' he loses a finger card. But he does get to re-set the 'Knipper' secretly so that no one else knows which side it will 'snap'. That's where the memory comes in. Players successfully reaching their own corner get a finger card back each time.

This fast and furious game of tension is for 2 to 4 players, the winner being the player who is the last with a finger or fingers intact.

40986.name: Kill The Sheep
40986.description:
The game can be played on any piece of paper, as long as you have two pencils and two players.

How the game works is simple. One player assumes the role of the sheep and one person assumes the role of the person trying to kill the sheep for various reasons. To start the game, a sheep is drawn on the page, preferably in the middle, then one person decides to go first and draw something on the page. Remember, the sheep is trying to escape the traps of the killer while the killer is trying to kill the sheep. The game eventually reaches a point when one person or the other is trapped, and has died. This can be over in a few minutes or drag on into a philosophical debate. The choice is up to you!

40987.name: Martianopoly
40987.description:
Move around the board cutting down trees to erect buildings.
The pieces are used as both currency and buildings.
Movement and payment options add strategy.

40988.name: Warband
40988.description:
Warband is a skirmish game based on the Hundred Kingdoms Mass Combat System. Using similar rules to the mass combat system, Warband allows new players to get a taste of the system without committing to purchasing an army.

The objective in Warband is to maintain control of a strategic point on the battlefield for a set number of turns (usually 5) or destroy all of your enemies.

In Warband, each individual miniature is a unit, each unit may receive only one command each turn, unless modified by a spell or special ability. Possible commands are

1. Non-combat Movement
2. Charge into Melee Combat
3. Melee Combat
4. Missile Combat
5. Rally
6. Disengage
7. Sorcery

In addition to these commands, you may have to deal with the mandatory command Retreat. Each player in turn issues all commands to his forces, resolves all effects, then play passes to the next player.

Warbands are built using a point based system, before play begins players choose their Kingdom, and may only marshal forces from that Kingdom. Full rules, army lists, and point costs are downloadable for free at the company website. While Black Orc would of course prefer you bought your minis from them, the game can be tried out with the miniatures you have on hand, and the downloaded information.

Boxed sets contained everything to get started, including

The rule book
Testors acrylic paints and paint brush
Miniatures painting guide
Flexible ruler
Two 20 sided dice

A Bushido Clan Strike Force consisting of
a. Ashigaru Spearman
b. Bushido Bowman
c. Samurai
d. Geisha Assassin
e. Wuxia Warrior

A Panthera Tribe hunting party consisting of
a. Jaguar Javelin Thrower
b. Jaguar Archer
c. Tiger Swordsman
d. Black Panther Assassin
e. Lioness Captain

40989.name: Crimson Skies: Spicy Air Tales
40989.description: Supplements to FASA's 1998 Crimson Skies (a game of aerial combat), the two volumes were more than just flavor text. Spicy Air Tales Vol.1 and Spicy Air Tales Vol.2 provided additional scenarios to play with the base game, adding some of the features disclosed in the contained stories.

boardgamehonor: 2010 Golden Geek Best Party Board Game Nominee
2010 Mensa Select Winner
40990.description:
In Word on the Street, players – either individually or in teams – try to claim letter tiles from the game board.

To set up the game, seventeen letter tiles (all the consonants in English other than j, q, x, and z) are placed in a strip down the center of the game board – the median strip of the street, if you will, which has two "traffic lanes" on either side of it. On a turn, one team is presented with a category such as "types of fruit" or "something a player is wearing", and that team has thirty seconds to come up with an answer in that category, then move the letters in that word toward their side of the game board. Any letters in the word that are not on the game board are skipped. If the answer were "pineapple", for example, the team would move P, N, P, P and L.

If a team moves a letter off the game board, it has claimed that letter and that tile will not move for the remainder of the game. The first team to claim eight letter tiles wins!
boardgameversion: English first edition with Mensa Select
40990.name: Word on the Street
boardgamepodcastepisode: BGWS 062 – Word on the Street
Episode 23 – We talk about the games we played
Game Glimpse #3: Word On The Street
GSL023-Word_Games
Session Impressions: Word On the Street
The Spiel #98 - Lighter Fare
TPGC - Episode #8 - Word on the Street and Funglish

40992.name: Extreme!
40992.description: A hotter and more challenging version of the popular He & She game! As in the basic version, you play in pairs and answer to questions dealing with your partner and relationship. But now there are also more difficult challenges – for example, you have to know what kind of things irritate your partner the most, and what kind of things he/she is really fond of. If you are able to put three answer alternatives in the same order, you get to move forward on the game board.

40993.name: Animals of the World
40993.description: A fun, educational game about animals for the whole family! The game contains 200 cards filled with interesting questions and facts about 200 different species all over the world. Play the easier version where you recognize the animals and answer questions about them – or try the more challenging version and see if you know the animal’s range, conservation status and Latin name as well!

40996.name: Race Cars: Tracks and Drivers
40996.description:
In this simple roll-and-roll game, players roll dice and then move their Hot Wheels-style race cars around a large (22"x36") mounted board featuring an oval race track. The winner is the first driver to complete 36 laps, enter the victory lane, and then land in the winner's circle.

The game is complicated slightly by Lap Cards and Pit Cards. Eight Lap Cards are drawn by each driver over the course of the game; these cards may instruct the players to move their cars or may indicate problems that require a visit to the pits. The driver must be able to enter pit road within two turns or suffer further consequences, and each driver must draw a Pit Card (which may further delay re-entry) upon leaving pit road.

Contents: 5 Racing Cars, 2 d6, 1 Score Pad for keeping track of laps and Lap Cards, 1 Game Board, 30 Pit Cards, and 40 Lap Cards

40997.name: Streets of Cairo
40997.description:
A very strategic tile laying and area control game that is highly interactive. The rules are easy to learn, winning requires cunning and clever play.

What treasures lay within the undiscovered Tomb of Akhenaton? Its location is rumored to be contained in a great mosaic created by those that worshiped the legendary pharaoh. Pieces of this mysterious and valuable mosaic have been hidden for ages in Egypt's greatest city. Can you lead your team of archeologists to make the discovery of a lifetime?

Players place city tiles to form the map of old Cairo and secure mosaic pieces known to be found in its three great mosques. As the city is developed, the players will reveal hidden followers, temples and leaders in the "Cult of Akhenaton." These hidden features are scored both during in-game play and the final "end game" round. Only with a carefully planned strategy and well execute tactics will the player be able to amass the largest collection of mosaic pieces and reveal its hidden secrets.

40998.name: Oil Drills
40998.description:
The goal of the game is to build a collection of the deepest oil drills.
Each player will first place a bid on resources buying order. After placing the bids the resources are rolled and players in bid order can buy resources.
Using the bought resources the players can deepen their oil shafts. Usually a player can only do one build action but with the help of their train workers and helpers they can have more build actions.
At the end of the turn players can sell oil in order to gain money to help them build deeper shafts.
At the end of the game the player with the best shafts depth combination wins. However, if a player catches a place of a possible deep shaft and does not build it as deep as possible he will get a penalty. Remember, money is just a tool in the game and not a goal!

40999.description:
The Dogfight Battles of July and August 1942
Rommel's success was inspiring, even to his sworn enemies. Time after time, his panzers swept across the desert like hot sirocco winds in their unrelenting blitzkrieg fashion. The British were nearing their end, so it seemed. Whatever defenses they created did little to halt Rommel. The Germans were also nearing their end logistically speaking as El Alamein was far, far away from their main supply depots. Rommel's own panzers were wearing out from all of the fast advances that had totally kept the British off balance.
The first of the grueling dogfight battles occurred from July 1-4. Hitler was pressing Rommel to go for the kill and reach the Nile. Rommel, himself, felt certain the British were at their end after the unraveling of their defenses in June and their chaotic retreat. But his DAK divisions had suffered and most were really just regimental size. Panzer divisions had a mere 30 tanks. Still, he went forth confident. In this battle, fuel was not an issue, but Rommel attacked without much intelligence as to where the enemy really was. For the British, it was their last stand. They could not afford another Gazala or Tobruk because it would mean Egypt was German.
The second dogfight battle in the same area began August 30th. Rommel would once again try his sweep around the end tactic and block all retreat routes. The battle is also known as Alam Halfa. Rommel had replenished his panzer divisions this time but fuel was a keen issue, as his plan called for them to advance deep into the rear of the British and cut them off. The problem was that his panzers would then have little fuel. By now, Rommel was more hesitant in this offensive and secured guarantees from Hitler that more fuel would arrive. Hitler promised. Reluctant, the order was again given in what was his last attempt to reach the Nile. The British were well prepared this time around and more or less knew of the plan. Their minefields were widened, units were instructed to let the German's come to them, their bombers readied. Dogfight 2 ended on Sept. 3, and the British lost a precious chance to encircle the DAK.

There are two games distinct from one another. Each uses different rules, counters and maps. They are at different scales with dogfight 2 being more tactical and dogfight 1, operational.
Each day turn in dogfight 1 is 8 hrs, 1 mile hexes. In dogfight 2, it is 4 hrs, and most units are company size. AFVs have armor ratings using a new system. Each game has 11x17" map and has 280 counters.
40999.name: Rommel at El Alamein, July & August

41000.description:
The stormy waters at the Southern Cone of the Americas saw very little fighting during the Second World War. But that didn't keep staff officers from the South American navies and the Royal Navy from wondering what would happen if the Axis fleets did penetrate into the region. U.S. Army Chief of Staff Gen. George C. Marshall considered a Japanese attempt to damage or destroy the Panama Canal to be the likely opening move of a war in the Pacific, making the sea lanes around Tierra del Fuego vital to the Allied war effort.

Strait of Magellan is a supplement for the Second World War at Sea series. There are ten scenarios, or separate game situations, based on battles that might have taken place in these waters, but ultimately did not. This module is not playable by itself, but requires ownership of our Cone of Fire, Midway, Bismarck and Leyte Gulf games and our East of Suez supplement.

Strait of Magellan is sold BOTH via .pdf download and as a printed booklet - you only need one.
41000.name: Second World War at Sea: Strait of Magellan

40501.name: Euroraces
40501.description: A table board game that was created by the Bank of Greece to promote the usage and knowledge of the new European currency called "Euro". The players are given cash in various denominations, and the object of the game is to visit as many as European destinations as possible and spend all the cash. The back of the board illustrates all the coinage and paper bill denominations of the new currency. The entire description is in greek language.

40502.name: Clovis
40502.description: In CLOVIS players represent hunter-gatherer bands of North America in 12,000 B.C. Players send out hunting parties to kill big game. This earns players points. Players may increase the numbers in their bands thus allowing them to kill more big game. There are specialty cards that modify the regular flow of things as well. The big game grow extinct as the game progresses. The game starts with 8 big game cards available in round 1 and only 1 big game card available for the final (8th) round.

40503.description:
Back of the box:

"You've heard the old saying: "Birds of a feather flock together"? Well, the same is true when they gather on wires -- that is, before they get zapped and fly away!

On their own power lines, players arrange birds into sets of three, trying to match the same color, the same size, all different colors, or all different sizes.

Birds on a Wire includes two sets of rules: one for families with children 7 and up and another for more advanced play."
40503.name: Birds on a Wire

40504.name: Crazy Office
40504.description: Will you be able to survive in the craziest office in the world with clumsy colleagues and awkward situations. To be able to "survive" you will have to use all your diplomatic skills: the ability to come out from difficult situations, to appear good to you bosses, to make your colleagues guilty ... like in a real office. Crazy Office will test your diplomatic and dialectic skills

40505.name: Sandokan: La Tigre della Malesia
40505.description:
Simple Italian game for children, from TV cartoons in late '90.
Interestingly, movement is determine by use of chips.
Each player plays the role of Sandokan.
He must reach the fortress where Marianna is trapped, set her free and return back to Monpracen.
The first to do this wins the game.

40506.description: The second book of army lists for Phil Barker's DBMM with conversion notes for DBM. A total of 84 lists are included.
40506.name: DBMM Army Lists Book 2: 500 BC to 476 AD

40507.name: Skip-Bo junior
40507.description:
From the instructions:
"Each player is dealt a "Stockpile" of 10 to 15 cards (depending on the number of players). The aim of the game is to get rid of these cards by creating Building Piles of cards in numerical sequence from 1 through 10. A player is also dealt a Hand of 3 new cards face up at the beginning of his/her turn which are used to assist in playing the Stockpile."

boardgamehonor: 2010 JoTa Best Game Released in Brazil Nominee
40508.description:
It's the Scrabble Slam Card Game! You're gonna love this fun twist on America's favorite word game -- Scrabble! Impress all your friends with your vast vocabulary and extensive knowledge of the English language!

In this fast-paced card game based on Scrabble, each player is dealt a hand of two-sided cards: each one has a different letter on each side, and a pair of letters in the corners that note which letters are on each face. Players create a four-letter word to start the game, then replace one letter at a time with cards from their hands. The first player to get rid of all their cards wins.
40508.name: Scrabble Slam!

boardgamehonor: 2009 Origins Awards Best Miniature Game Rules Winner
40509.description:
Another volume in the Classic Battletech core rules series, Strategic Operations focuses on "forces in solar system" (as opposed to "forces on world" for Tactical Operations and the even-wider-ranging scope of the forthcoming Interstellar Operations). This book's main sections consist of general rules covering a variety of topics (including a system for abstracted aerospace gaming); rules for advanced aerospace movement, combat, and unit construction; maintenance, repair, salvage, and customization rules; and miniatures rules (as opposed to using miniatures on a standard hex maps).

A significant portion of the volume is taken up with standard and advanced rules for a revised version of Battleforce 2, a fast-playing game system amenable to mass combat. Rules for converting standard Battletech units to Battleforce are also included.

Strategic Operations updates not only Battleforce but also BattleTech: AeroTech 2, integrating both into the current rules framework.

Expands:
BattleTech
Classic Battletech: Total Warfare

Re-implements:
Battleforce 2
BattleTech: AeroTech 2
40509.name: Classic Battletech: Strategic Operations

40510.name: Monopoly: My MLB Edition
40510.description:
Inroducing the first ever Monopoly game you customize! Choose 22 of the 30 Major League Baseball teams and place them on the board.

Then . . . buy, sell and trade your favorite teams in an effort to control Major League Baseball, a baseball fan's fantasy. The team labels are removeable and reusable so, if you choose, you can play a different game each time.

Create It . . . Play It . . . Own It All!

40511.description:
In this game, the rules of chess are exactly the same, but the geometry is completely different. As long as you carefully follow the rules for the movement of the pieces, you will be O.K., but the geometry of a concave surface can make things confusing.

Two lines can intersect in more than one point. That means that a queen has two different ways to get from point A to point B. A bishop can change colors and you can even end up with two bishops on the same color. A rook in the center of the board controls two adjacent rows. If a knight is near the center, it can land on the same color as the square it left.

You can win by either checkmating an opponent or by taking enough pieces of value from your opponents before being checkmated. Thus, aggressive play is often rewarded. There is a small score board with wooden discs to keep track of points earned (better pieces are worth more points).
40511.name: Hyperbolic Chess

40512.name: Shove piecepack
40512.description:
Shove Ha'penny is a traditional British pub (tavern) game of dexterity and skill dating from the the mid
19th Century, with earlier variants in existence as early as the 15th Century. It is still widely played
today. Shove piecepack is an adaptation of this fun game for all ages.

It adds a new definition to the piecepack glossary:

Shove (v.): to propel/push an object (overhanging the edge of a table) along a smooth surface, by hitting it with the heel of one’s hand.

Rules can be found on Piecepack Wiki

Game System

Piecepack Game System

40513.name: Ahoy, Matey!
40513.description: Ahoy, Matey! is a rip-roaring pirate adventure for ye olde piecepack. It has been ported and adapted from Scott Peterson's web-infamous 'Pirateer'. It is a fun mix of luck, luck, luck and skill for all of the family. There are almost endless variants that you can use to spice the game up even further. The object is to collect the treasure with one of your ships and move it to the Ace coin in your harbor.

40514.name: Scrabble Apple
40514.description:
Take a BITE out of this JUICY game!

Flip over the tiles, one at a time. The first to make a new word, or build off an oponent's word, gets the word and the points. (Red tile double your word score.) Think fast, or your words will get swiped before you can say, "SCRABBLE Apple!" To win, have the most points when the tiles are gone. It's a very a-peel-ing way to polish up your word-forming skills!

40515.name: A Knight's Tale
40515.description:
"What say you, Brave Knight?". A piecepack port of Joe Huber's Joust (in theme of Heath Ledger's "A Knight's Tale"). A Fast-paced, very simple, and fun game. There is a slight element of strategy (in the style of Rock, Paper, Scissors). The game is perfect to kick-start a gaming session.

Pre-programmed movement and attacks lead to interesting strategy!

Rules can be found on Piecepack Wiki

Game System

Piecepack Game System

40516.name: ran: SAT.1-Fußballquiz
40516.description: ran - SAT.1-Fußballquiz is a trivia game about football, respectively soccer. In their turns, the players throw a dice, move across the board and answer one out of 999 questions concerning football. The one, who reaches the finish first and can answer three questions consecutively is the winner.

40517.name: Thomas The Tank Engine Game
40517.description:
Two, three or four engines collect their trains and race to the seaside.

Make a complete train of one engine and three trucks or carriages by collecting from two sidings and a third at a station. Who will win by having the first train to arrive at the seaside station?

Simple roll and move game for children based on the popular books and TV show.

40518.description:
Mr Bump's job is picking apples. He does it by bumping into apple trees, that's why this game is named after him. The object of the game is to "Bump" all the apples from the tree and when the last apple has been picked the player with the most apples is the winner.

Each player sits facing one of the four 'apple tubs'. All apples are placed round the tree playing surface just like apples on a tree. Each player spins the spinner and takes or puts back apples from the tree or his tub as directed by where the spinner stops.

Very simple spin-and-move game for kids, but with little plastic apples and apple tubs for added appeal.
40518.name: Mr Bump's Apple Picking Game

40519.description:
ASLComp First Wave at Omaha brings the fury of Bloody Omaha to the ASLComp players in the most massive historical module yet published. This game is a historical module for the Advanced Squad Leader system. It has three linking maps recreate Omaha West and portions of Omaha East with six feet of running map length. Every detail is there, and all of the Vierville and Les Moulins draws, scenes of the hardest fighting in Normandy and the setting for the opening scene of Saving Private Ryan, are included.

The 'three story house', Norman 'Dutch' Cota, wave after wave of landing craft, laden with American soldiers headed for their doom...or the first step in freeing Hitler's Fortress Europa.

The packet will contain mostly enough counters to play the module with player providing fortification counters, US & German concealment counters and possibly some information counters.

ASLComp First Wave at Omaha contains:

* 15 action-packed scenarios
* 1 monster campaign style scenario that depicts the entire landing and battle inland
* 3 linking color maps
* 8 page variant Special Rules booklet
* 10 116th Regimental Combat Team Landing Play Aids
* 4 German Resistance Nest Play Aids
* 2 Destroyer Cards
* 6 sheets of color die cut counter
* Color Cover sheet
* Backsheet
* Ziploc® style baggie to hold it all in
40519.name: First Wave at Omaha

40520.name: Aqeuropoly
40520.description:
Aqeuropoly covers 4 continents and 24 countries. Your musketeer (player) journeys with the aim of setting up companies in the various countries. The end goal is to dominate a continent with large holding companies.

Players gain points by offering different services and holding companies and having the largest market share. Players may simply build and start companies or can do a hostile take-over of other opponents companies.

40521.description:
Rhodos 1522 is a solitaire wargame covering the war between the Turks and the Crusaders on Rhodos in 1522. The game itself is card-driven and battles are resolved by dice rolling.

The game is free for download for print and play, however rules, cards and map are all in German.

Download link: http://www.ghs-kosim.de/index.php/cosimm/rhodosm
40521.name: Rhodos 1522

40522.name: Jade
40522.description:
Two players, Cross and Parallel, take turns placing a stone of either color at a vacant board point. Cross wins by connecting all four sides with a chain of either color. Parallel wins by connecting either the top and bottom or left and right sides with two chains, one of each color. Draws are not possible.

The game can be played on Richard's PBeM server:
http://www.gamerz.net/pbmserv/jade.html

40523.description: Tintenherz Das Spiel zum Film is an abstract tile game based upon the film (Inkheart, in English), featuring scenes from the film. Players move around the board, looking for matched pairs as in a memory game. Each player takes the role of a character from the film, receiving a related special action to take during the game.
40523.name: Tintenherz: Das Spiel zum Film

40524.name: Cyclisme Manager
40524.description: French cycling game base on peloton movement rather than on individual riders' movement.

40525.name: Jvgec
40525.description: French cycling game, the name stands for 'jeu de vélo et gestion d'une équipe cycliste'.

40526.name: Tour de France
40526.description: French cycling game about the Tour de France. Each player has a team of three cyclists and a series of tactics cards. Cyclists move by groups and players can use their tactics cards to help them. The race is composed of different zones like Sprint or Mountain. Race Event can appear in specific zones determined by Event Cards. Players can win on three different classifications : General, Sprint or Mountain.

40528.name: ElvisOpoly
40528.description:
ElvisOpoly

"The Rock 'n' Roll Game of Fortune & Fame"

This is a monopoly style game about Elvis Presley. Players move around a board featuring Elvis songs and collect gold or platinum records. Board spaces include Graceland and the U.S. Army.

Includes board, cards, plastic record discs, tokens, play money, dice, rules, and storage insert.

(c)1995

boardgamehonor: 1991 Origins Awards Best Fantasy or Science Fiction Boardgame Winner
40529.description:
Players represent alien races that are seeking to spread themselves onto five foreign worlds. To accomplish this, they make challenges against other players and enlist the aid of interested parties. But alien powers, which are unique to each race, give players ways to bend or outright break some rule in the game.

This is an updated version of the original Eon Cosmic Encounter (1977).

Major differences between this version and the Eon version:


Flares in the Mayfair version are "use once and discard", as opposed to Eon's version, which lets players reuse them.
Moons (in the More Cosmic Encounter expansion) have text written on them (instead of only a number which you used to refer to a separate list). Moons also were divided into four categories: Full Moons have a major effect on the game; Half Moons are more moderate in their effects; Quarter Moons have a minor effect; Cheese Moons introduce silliness to the game.
Lucre (in the More Cosmic Encounter expansion) was revamped with additional uses, and players were required to spend it to affect their challenge totals.
Mayfair introduced a new card: Reinforcements, as well as new Edicts, and several new Alien Powers with corresponding Flares.
Mayfair introduced phase / timing icons on all Powers, Flares, and Edicts to clearly indicate when each could be used.


Expanded by:

More Cosmic Encounter




Re-implements:

Eon's Cosmic Encounter (1977)




Re-implemented by:

Simply Cosmic, Mayfair's simplified version
40529.name: Cosmic Encounter
boardgamepodcastepisode: I've Been Diced! episode 17: The enduring appeal of Cosmic Encounter
Little Metal Dog Show - Episode 17

40530.name: Rukshuk:  Pagota
40530.description:
Pagota is the sequel to the award-winning stacking game, Rukshuk.

The goal of Pagota is to build tall towers using stones valued at 1 through 5 points. At any time a player may bow out and take the sum amount of their points, rather than risk building their tower higher.

boardgamehonor: 2001 Spiel der Spiele Hit mit Freunden Recommended
40531.description:
In Cosmic Encounter, you play the leader of a colonization effort whose ships are traveling throughout the Cosmos to prove their worthiness for Cosmic leadership. Each player is a race that has the ability to bend or break certain rules in the game. You will use force, cunning, and diplomacy to win success for your unique form of alien intelligence. Battles are determined through the use of cards in addition to assistance from other players around the table. The winner(s) will be the first player(s) to have FIVE COLONIES on any planets outside his or her home system.

This is an updated version of the original Cosmic Encounter (1977).

Major differences between this version and the Eon version:


Terminology was changed for many components and rules: Compromise to Negotiate; Consolation to Compensation; Edicts to Artifacts, etc.
Both the Eon version and Mayfair Games' version used tokens to represent players' forces. Avalon Hill changed them to plastic ships, and changed the system pieces as well, and the Hyperspace Cone became a Ship carrier.
Mayfair's version used cardback art similar to Eon's, so the two could theoretically be combined. Avalon Hill used all new art on the cards, and the stock is much thinner.
40531.name: Cosmic Encounter
boardgamepodcastepisode: I've Been Diced! episode 17: The enduring appeal of Cosmic Encounter
Little Metal Dog Show - Episode 17

40532.name: Big Day Dice Games
40532.description:
This simple black felt bag comes with 2 shiny metal 6-sided dice and a rulebook for 5 unique games. These games include:

Around the Horn = Players split into 2 teams, that line up on opposite sides of a table. Starting with the players at one end of the table, each team is given one die to roll. Players race to roll a 6 and then pass the die. The first team to have all players successfully roll a 6 wins.

Face-Off = 2 players go head-to-head rolling one die each. Low roller pays the high roller the difference in chips. Ties are paid by both players into a common pot in the center.

Dealer's Dice = Players take turns being the "dealer". The other players put a number of fingers on the table to guess what the dealer will roll. If you are right other players pay you their own finger-count in chips.

Wild Ride = A push-your-luck game where you keep rolling and add up the total of the dice for your score, but if you ever roll a six you bust and lose all your points for that turn. A double-six loses all your points you've accumulated for the entire game. First player to 75 points wins.

12 Down = Players write down the numbers 1 through 12 on paper and then take turns rolling to cover up as many numbers as possible. The numbers you can cover are ones that add up to the same total as your die roll. The player with the most numbers covered wins.

boardgamecompilation: Zooloretto: Rio Grande Games Expansion Pack #2
40533.description:
There are three different type of coworker tiles in this expansion.

The Training Area
When you earn a coworker, you may take possession of the Training Pool (if available) and place your worker there. For each trainer you place here (up to 2) each animal in your aquarium with a lightning bolt gets 2 bonus points. Also, all your animals with lightning bolts are no longer untrainable. So you can get additional bonus points from each trainer you place next to them in your main Water Zoo!

The Research Station
Can only be taken by a player when they get their first coworker. That coworker is placed on one animal tile in his water park and at the end of the game he scores one point for each animal of that type in the basin the coworker was placed.

The Technical Area
Take when you have a coworker you want to place on the tile. Immediately collect five coins from the bank. You may now move, purchase, and discard tiles from the depot independent of the stack order, but you may not change the order of the tiles in the stack.

Aquaretto: The Training Camp part of this expansion was originally released as a postcard.

This expansion was part of Zooloretto: Rio Grande Games Expansion Pack #2 for Zooloretto, which also included Zooloretto: Job Boards, Zooloretto: The Gorilla, Zooloretto: The Savings Book, and Aquaretto: The Trains.

And is also part of the german only Zooloretto News #2.

Also available as part of the Zooloretto: Goodie-Box.
40533.name: Aquaretto: Three Coworker Tiles

40534.name: alea
40534.description: The components are colored tops and an hexagonal board with numbered holes. Throw your top and score the number of the hole where your top stops.

40535.name: Onset
40535.description:
Dale's Woodcraft has manufactured a visually appealing wooden folding game board with 6 rows of 12 columns numbered 1 - 12 with each of the 6x12 intersections a depression to fit the marbles. The game stores 24 marbles (12 each of 2 colors), 4 dice, and 4 scoring pegs. Each round consists of 12 points and first to win 2 rounds wins the game.

Depending on the roll of two die, the optional use of a decreasing "reinforcement" number, and the management of the lower non-scoring columns to absorb part of the roll, each player moves a combination of marbles across the board towards and into the opponent's territory scoring points along the way and eventually blocking the movement of their opponent (unless the opponent blocks them first!).

This game involves luck of the dice along with the management of a reinforcement number and non-scoring columns to enable a strategy of movement for a fast moving game that is simple to play.

40536.description:
Octago is a Game for the Yvio Boardgame Console. An Yvio Console is needed to play.
In Octago you move around the board trying to pick up points. The board consists of 12 spaces showing each a symbol in a certain color. The longer nobody steps on a space / symbol / color the more points you get for entering the space. The console does all the bookkeeping, which makes the complex scoring mechanism possible.
40536.name: Yvio: Octago

40537.name: Big Pay Day
40537.description:
From the publisher:

The classic game of making and spending money, just got a whole lot bigger with Big Payday. Now with more money, more deals (Double Deals & Super Steals!) more mail, more tokens AND an innovative, customizable 2-level game board.

40538.name: Emmacubes Sumfun
40538.description:
There are 24 cubes with numbers and other mathematical symbols on the sides in the box.

From the box cover: Divide the cubes between 2-4 players who then proceed to construct their own separate sum (all cubes must be used) as example below:-
9x9=81
A player on completion of sum may call sumfun when all play must stop. Answers of completed (and correct) sums count as score. Redeal and play up to five games for set.

40539.name: Professor Quizzle's Quiz Wizard Trivia: Television
40539.description: Basic deck of cards with trivia questions about television programs. Can be added to any other trivia game for extended fun.

40540.name: Arena DeathMatch
40540.description:
From publisher's website:

Welcome to Arena Deathmatch!

Avatars of War: Arena DeathMatch is a 28mm miniatures game that depicts the bloody clash between two or more bands of heroes facing off on the floor of the arena, in front of a raucous crowd that is thirsty for action, violence and death. This deadly contest is known as a deathmatch.

The most powerful heroes among the mortal races are known as Avatars of War--heroes chosen by the Gods of War themselves. These Avatars, in addition to being fierce combatants, are able to draw upon the silver of divinity within their souls for the power to expand their already awesome combat abilities.

In Arena DeathMatch, each player controls a band of Avatars of War as they face off on the arena floor in front of a cheering (or jeering) crowd.

The perils of the Arena stand against you: traps, hazards and even savage beasts stand between you and your opponent. The door to the Arena opens, and the shouting crowd is eager to see their favourite heroes fight to the death. Will they be cheering your victory...or your death? There's only one way to find out!

40541.name: Brew-HaHa
40541.description:
Brew-HaHa - The Official Beer Nutz Comix Game by Wild Wigout Comix Game Boards.

A wonderful handmade silk-screened board game created by underground comic artist Wayno in the mid 1990s for the now extinct Scairy Hairy Toys which was previously located in San Fransisco, Ca.

To play the game you need a case or three of cheap, cheap beer, shot glasses, and the song Rubber Biscuit by The Chips (easily found on the web)....

The object of the game is to out-drink your opponents while moving your drunken game piece around the board and staying conscious yourself. The winner of the game is the last one standing and/or resisting the urge to throw-up especially when dancing and singing along to the great hit song "Rubber Biscuit" performed by The Chips circa 1956. Yes, anytime a player lands on the Rubber Biscuit space everyone has to jump up and shout Rubber Biscuit, Rubber Biscuit!!! while dancing to the song. Any player returning their cheap beer rental via the porcelain god is immediately disqualified and is banished to pass out in the bathtub.

40542.name: Wygraj z maturą
40542.description:
Polish game designed specially to help students to pass the high school exams. It's designed for the Ministry of Education by a group of grad teachers. It has 3000 questions in five different categories: Polish language/literature, history, geography, English language, others (culture, art, philosophy...).

Components:
- board
- dice
- pawns
- 360 cards with questions
- 60 cards "chance".

Official website: http://www.wygrajzmatura.pl

40543.name: Knight's Domain
40543.description:
Knight's Domain is played with similar rules to chess. Each side has only three types of pieces, 8 Knights, 3 pawns, and 1 King. The object is to Checkmate your opponents King. The King is restricted to movement within a 6 space area called the "King's Vale" at the rear of his board.

Game components as published include:
1 9x8 board with "Vale" area clearly marked
2 kings
16 Knights
6 pawns
instructions.

40544.description: A tabletop wargaming rule system designed to give players a real flavour for the tactics and troops used in Europe during the period 1660-1721. The game play is simple and quick to master. The mechanics are based on simultaneous movement regulated by easy to understand orders. The game can be played in 28mm or 15mm scale. 6-8 units per side will give two or three hours of fun. The rules will easily accommodate 100 units per side for grand battle scenarios. The 2nd edition has many refined mechanisms for orders, shooting, close combat and morale. The book has an updated events section with 52 ‘playing card’ controlled game events to add challenges and entertainment to the game play. The rules contain supplementary chapters for gaming the Great Northern War, Eastern Wars against the Ottoman Empire and King William’s War in North America 1689-1690.
40544.name: Beneath the Lily Banners

40545.description:
Quinquereme is an extension module to the War Galley game by GMT. This module is found in GMT's C3I Issue #12.

Scenarios:

Ebro, 217 BC Rome vs. Carthage
Clupea, 208 BC Rome vs. Carthage




Expands:

War Galley
40545.name: Quinquereme

40546.description:
A Down in Flames Campaign from RBM/GMT's C3i Magazine Nr12.

Contents:
Background and rules
Campaign Sheet
2 sheets of Down in Flames aircraft
40546.name: Down in Flames: Arab-Israeli War 1948-'49

40547.name: Moose Boose
40547.description:
Bring a miniaturized classic country fair atmosphere into your own home. Filled with moose calls, bidding and trading, Moose Boose gives a whole new meaning to the half-and-half concept.

Own the winning square by purchasing from or trading with your opponents. But be careful! The winning square might already be yours right from the start! Moose Boose is a strategic game of luck and is ideal for entertaining the whole family and friends.

Apportez à la maison l'ambiance des foires agricoles en un classique miniaturisé. Agrémenté de cris d'orignal, d'enchères et d'échanges, Moose Boose réinvente le concept des moitié-moitié.

Procurez-vous la case gagnante en achetant ou en échangeant avec vos adversaires. Mais attention! Il se peut que vous possédiez la bonne case dès le départ! Moose Boose est un jeu de hasard stratégique, idéal et «orignal» pour amuser toute la famille et les amis.

40548.name: Super Gachapon Fighter
40548.description:
Super Gachapon Fighter is a tabletop/miniatures fighting game ruleset designed for 2-4 players.

Players create their own personalized fighter (using any figures or miniatures you have at hand) and take to the streets for one on one or team based combat. Make any tabletop a arena to stage your bouts.

Use fireballs, combos or grapples to pound your opponent into submission. Or build up your charge meter and unleash a Super Move!

Visit www.gachafighter.com and download the Demo rules!!

40549.name: Guard du Corps
40549.description: Guard du Corps can be used with 25mm, 15mm or even 5/6mm scale models. Guard du Corps is played on a 1 to 60 scale with 1 turn equalling 15 minutes. The game comes with a Rules book, and Army (unit) Data book, and a set of 12 game charts.

boardgameimplementation: Star Trek: Customizable Card Game (first edition)
40550.description: Star Trek CCG 2nd edition is a reinvention of the original star trek customizable card game. One major difference in Second Edition was the addition of a cost system to equipment, events, personnel, and ships. A card's cost is listed in the top left-hand corner of a card, directly preceding the card's title as a single digit number (currently anywhere from 0 to 9). A player receives seven 'counters' at the beginning of each turn; to play a card, the player must spend a number of counters equal to the cost of the card. Only interrupts (of the card types in a player's deck) do not have a cost and are treated as 0-cost.Another major change in the gameplay of Second Edition was the new method of handling dilemmas. Instead of using First Edition's lengthy procedure of a 'seed phase', which could last upwards of 15 minutes, Second Edition employs an 'on-the-fly' method for constructing dilemma combinations. While First Edition attempted to sometimes literally represent instances from the Star Trek universe in the game, Second Edition has focused more on a consistency of gameplay as a priority over design consideration with regard to remaining faithful to the source material. Effects on cards sometimes lack the "Trek sense" that First Edition cards contained and can be purely conceptual, but are generally much more equitable when compared with other similarly costed effects.
40550.name: Star Trek Customizable Card Game (Second Edition)

40551.name: Emil räumt auf!
40551.description: In this game based on children's books by Janosch, the players have to recycle several types of garbage, like scrap paper, bulk garbage or organic waste. The player, who can dispose of his waste on the right spots on the board first, wins.

40552.name: Equine Trivia
40552.description:
Equine Trivia, The Game

Players answer questions about horses and equestrian sports as they attempt to advance to the Championship Round.

Includes a colorful board, tokens, dice, score chips, rules, question cards, storage box, and rules.

The game features an unusual packaging concept: it comes in a plastic tote box.

(c)1984

40553.name: Coppa Santagostino
40553.description: Italian cycling game released to promote a manufacturer of socks (!?). Played on a board measuring 49x34cm.

40554.name: Escape from Zyzzlvaria
boardgamepublisher: The Evil Midnight Bombers What Bomb at Midnight
40554.description:
Escape from Zyzzlvaria is a board game whose existence was first announced at the 2002 MIT Mystery Hunt in Cambridge, Massachusetts, and then debuted seven years later at ZyzzlCon during the 2009 MIT Mystery Hunt. Only 75 production copies were printed.

The game features a board, 12 polyhedral dice, a deck of 16 cards, 8 pawns, 8 escape pods, 370 dollar bucks, a Moon Counter, and a Wheel of Death. The object of the game is to get as many members of the crew of the Brass Rat out of Zyzzlvaria before the moon counter reaches Eclipse!

The game's primary designer is Foggy Brume, based on concepts from a puzzle by Dan Katz.

http://escapefromzyzzlvaria.com/

http://www.mit.edu/~puzzle/09/puzzles/The_Board_Game/

40555.name: La Segunda Guerra Mundial 2ªParte, Frente del Pacífico
40555.description:
The 7th of December 1941, Japanese troops without previously declaring war, launched an attack to the US NAVY, based at Pearl Harbor.

This game represents the war in the Pacific Ocean

40556.name: Das Camp
40556.description:
Youth leaders can test their knowledge with this game. The game is about the organization, performance and evaluation of children in a youth camp.
The game is played with 2 to 4 teams with at least 3 gamers. The game map is divided in three parts which symbolize the three phases of a youth camp. The teams have to go trough these phases and resolve the duties and responsibilities which they get by cards. The team which is first to reach their goal wins.

40557.name: Benthos
40557.description:
"7 Major International Companies are developing the Worlds Ocean Resources. Players buy stocks in these companies and control how they grow. Board Game for 2-7 players."

The game is played on a 10x10 grid using tiles and cubes. Also required for play are Stock cards, paper money (or any reasonable substitute), and a scoring track. The board is randomly filled with tiles at the start of the game.

The game lasts for five rounds. During each round there are seven turns. Each turn starts with the players bidding for control of a single share of stock from one of the seven companies. The player winning the bid operates the company for that round (represented by placing cubes on the board). These operations determine the value of the company, which in turn determines the amount of money paid as dividends to the stockholders for that company.

Once seven turns have been played, one for each company, the round ends and dividends are paid to stockholders. The winner is the player with the most money at the end of the game.

40559.name: Trivial Pursuit: Family
40559.description:
This is a new 2008 version that has cards for adults and cards for children with different types of questions.

This edition is only sold in Target.

OBJECT
To be the first player to fill all six spaces on your Scoring Token with different colored wedges by correctly answering questions. Get back to the center first and answer a final question correctly to win!

The dark blue cards are for players aged 14 or older. The bright blue cards are for younger players. Decide who should play from what deck at the start of the game and always return cards to the appropriate deck

WEDGE SPACES
There are six spaces around the board with a picture of a large colored wedge. If you answer a question correctly when you land on a wedge space, place a matching-colored scoring wedge into your scoring token! Then roll the die and take another turn.

ROLL AGAIN SPACES
When you land on one of these spaces, you may roll the die again.

SHORTCUT SPACES
There are six spaces around the board with a picture of a small colored wedge. When you land on one of these shortcut spaces by exact count, move directly to the matching-colored wedge space. Answer the question correctly to win a wedge of that color.

Short Game
In this version of the game, you don’t have to land on a wedge space to win a wedge. Instead, every time you get a correct answer, you win a matching-colored wedge.

QUESTION CATEGORIES

BLUE ...............Geography
PINK ...............Entertainment
YELLOW ........History
PURPLE ..........Art & Culture
GREEN ...........Science & Nature
ORANGE ........Sport & Leisure

40560.description:
Build the Kingdom - The Greatest Mission in the World is an LDS-themed game in which players attempt to gain the most converts in a game somewhat similar to Catan.

The board is a modular assortment of diamonds (rather than the hexes used in Catan) with each having a symbol representing a principle of the Mormon faith on it (Preach my Kingdom, Faith, Repentance, Baptism, and Prayer). Players gain the principles through die rolls and trade them in for converts, Books of Mormons, and churches - each of which is worth Celestial Points. Satan (similar to Catan's Robber) moves about the game board hindering the work.

The game ends when a player achieves 10 Celestial Points.
40560.name: Build the Kingdom: The Greatest Mission in the World

40561.name: Curling Table Game
40561.description:
Curling Table Game is a dexterity curling simulation game in which one has the chance to act as a professional curler and slide the curling stones (made out of plastic and a metal sphere) down the game board. Hand coordination is vital as the stones react even to the smallest movements made when throwing them.

Basic curling rules are used although players can naturally decide how many ends to play at their own will. One end comprises of both teams throwing their eight stones in turns. At the end of an end the team whose stone is closest to the button is awarded one point for each of its own stones that are closer than the opponent's closest stone.

The game works well with 2, 4, or 8 players as the players are always separated into two competing teams. Curling Table Game is a fun social action game in which skill plays a big role.

boardgamehonor: 2007 Japan Boardgame Prize Best Childgame Nominee
40562.name: Tenplus
40562.description: A collection of three card based games from designer Susumu Kawasaki: Sums Ten, Countup Ten, and Hand Ten. The former plays with two or three players, while the others work for two to four players.

40563.description:
Starterbook: Wolf and Blake is the second volume in the Classic Battletech Starterbook series. Each book in the series is designed to act as a "bridge" between various Battletech products, making it easier for players to jump into an enriched but more complex game. While Classic Battletech Starterbook: Sword and Dragon serves as a link between the Battletech Introductory Box Set and the full tournament/standard rules found in Classic Battletech: Total Warfare, Starterbook: Wolf and Blake links Total Warfare to Classic Battletech: Tactical Operations, the on-world advanced core rulebook. Wolf and Blake also offers an introduction to the current Jihad storyline and to the religiously driven Word of Blake faction. The famed Black Widow Company serves as the opposing force.

Wolf and Blake follows the basic pattern laid out in Sword and Dragon: brief bits of fiction, profiles of each side's history and current Mechwarriors, a rules annex (here previewing some of the advanced rules from TacOps), a "warchest" campaign system, and a series of branching missions that players can explore. The book ends with a series of filled-in record sheets, including variant 'Mechs depicted in the text.

Total Warfare is required to use Starterbook: Wolf and Blake. Technical Readout: 3050 Upgrade is recommended.
40563.name: Classic Battletech Starterbook: Wolf and Blake

40564.name: Convention
40564.description:
A tabletop dexterity game where players flick wooden half-cylinders into each other, scoring points when a flicked piece hits another of the same orientation.

The 48 wooden pieces are tossed on the table. Those lying flat side down are called "Republicans", and those lying curved side down are called "Democrats". In addition, four of the wooden pieces are colored blue and deemed "Independents". Players attempt to flick a piece into another of the same affiliation, without hitting any other piece. Special rules detail the proper way of handling Independents and any maverick pieces that happen to land standing on end.

An odd marriage of Crokinole and Pass the Pigs.

40565.name: Bobby Hull Hockey Game
40565.description: Similar to the Munro Hockey game from 1931. This one of course is much more modern with a metal frame and metal players. This game has a automatic puck drop, scoreboard, goal lights that actually light up (requires 2 D-size batteries). The game also came with double players which could be used when you pulled your goalie for an added skater near the end of a close game. The game featured metal players from various original teams in the NHL.

40567.name: Chinese Dominoes
40567.description:
Chinese Dominoes

Chinese Dominoes is a family of domino games played with "Chinese Dominoes" (or also called Asian Dominoes, as there are Chinese, Korean, Burmese, and Thai games played with these sets of Dominoes).


Origins

The Chinese name for 'Chinese Dominoes' is K'wat P'ai (meaning "bone tablets") or sometimes U P'ai ("Barbarian tablets)

As with a number of other Chinese games these dominoes made their way to Korea. The Korean version of dominoes are called kol-hpai (meaning "bone tablets") or sometimes ho-hpai ("Barbarian tablets") - possibly linked to the attitude of the korean nobility towards the game.


Components

Chinese Dominoes differ from Western Dominoes in the number and distribution of the tiles, as well as the games that are traditionally played with them.

A set consists of 32 tiles of a double-six pattern, distributed as follows:
Two copies of 1-1, 1-3, 1-5, 1-6, 2-2, 3-3, 4-4, 4-6, 5-5, 5-6 and 6-6.
One copy of 1-2, 1-4, 2-3, 2-4, 2-5, 2-6, 3-4, 3-5, 3-6 and 4-5.

These differ from Western Dominoes in that they have no blanks. The tiles are made up of the 21 different combinations of two six-sided dice thrown, plus the 11 "duplicate copies" listed above.

The pips for one and four are colored red. All other numbers are white, with the exception of six, which is half-and-half. These colors have significance in the Chinese games. Asian Dice have the one and four pips colored red as well.

Pai Gow and Tien Gow are popular games played with Chinese Dominoes.

40568.name: Guard the Hive's Golden Treasure!
40568.description:
Guard the Hive's Golden Treasure! was published on the back of a Honey Nut Cheerios cereal box in 2008. The cereal box comes with a Magic Compass Decoder that is used in playing the game.

From the box:

Guard the Hive's Golden Treasure!

Buzz and his friends want to move the honey that makes Honey Nut Cheerios cereal so delicious across the amber ocean. But Yellow Jack and his crew won't make it easy!

To Play:
Help Buzz transport the honey across the ocean or challenge a friend to see who can get there first. To play, flip a coin to determine how many spaces to move. Heads move one space, tails moves two.

When you land on a compass, place your magic compass decoder on the spot and move it back and forth to reveal the symbol for your next move. Use the key to determine the value for each symbol.

40569.name: Zusammen mit den Kleinen Bären zählen lernen
40569.description:
The small bear collect berries. Do you want to accompany it? How many berries have you collected? Count with the small bear and experience the exciting counting world.

Every round you open a card and you receive berries. Last two rounds you have to give some berries to you left or right neighbors.
It trains little kids to count and share things with others.

40570.description:
Heirs of the Golden Horde (HGH) is the sixth volume of Red Sash Games Lace Wars series. The game is companion to Volume V, Türkenkrieg. The subject of both games is the little known Russo-Austro-Turkish War of 1735-39. Türkenkrieg dealt with the war between the Imperials (the Habsburg Austrian Empire) and the Ottoman Empire along the Danube. HGH investigates the theatre of the Ukraine, where the Russians attempted to destroy the power of the Crimean Tatars as a first step toward Peter the Great's dream of a warm water port.

On the Danube, the Ottoman Turks dealt a critical blow to Charles VI and the House of Habsburg, leading almost immediately to the War of the Austrian Succession (1740-48). In the Ukraine, things were different. Forgotten or dismissed as "futile" by historians, the campaigns of the Muscovites against the remnants of the Mongols' Golden Horde were in fact brutally effective.

8 scenarios and 1 Campaign

HGH is not a complete game. Although it is possible to play a few of the scenarios with the counter mix provided, HGH is intended to be an expansion module for Türkenkrieg (1737-1739).
40570.name: Heirs of the Golden Horde

40571.description:
Stratocracy is a grand strategy empire building game. 2-8 players will construct a modular board that is unique from game to game and take turns exploring the board, and coming into conflict with each other.

Players have a limited set of moves and military pieces they may use during the game, and are trying to be the first to win via one of two listed victory conditions (one based on exploration, the other based on battle).

The turn sequence is broken into three phases (Treasury, Movement, and Battles) and each player completes his turn fully before it is passed to the next player.

Advanced rules are provided which gives players access to a set of nine nation cards with unique abilities that will alter their play-style, as well as rules for faster play.

Stratocracy is part of a series of print and play boardgames published through Bell of Lost Souls. This series is provided as a downloadable pdf which includes everything needed to play except dice. Players may download, print out the pieces, and start playing. The game is designed to be enhanced with common playing pieces found in other games for those would prefer to not use counters.

STRATOCRACY is available FREE at BoLS Board Games: http://www.bolsboardgames.com
40571.name: Stratocracy

40572.description:
Centrifuge is a trick-taking game for 2 to 4 players, and was originally developed for the Decktet. Centrifuge makes unusual use of the dual-suitedness of the Decktet cards (Each card valued 2-9 has an "upper" and a "lower" suit depicted on it.), in that the led card's upper suit will be positive, and its lower suit will be negative. Subsequent cards may follow either suit, but those with the positive suit will be positive; those in the negative, negative. Cards sporting both suits (such as the card that was led) cancel themselves, due to having both the positive and negative suit.

If the total value of the cards in the trick is positive, then the highest card wins the trick - even if it's an off-suit card. If the total value of the cards in the trick is negative, then the lowest card wins the trick - even if it's an off-suit card. The ability of an off-suit card to win is the equivalent of a trump mechanism in Centrifuge. Another unusual feature is that it's possible for no one to win the trick.

Each player is playing to collect symbols of her own secret suit, indicated by an ace she was dealt at the beginning of the hand.

The game also supports partnership play (additionally offering a Cancellation variant). The two-player game also offers a Playing for Both Teams variant.
40572.name: Centrifuge

40573.name: Ming Mang
40573.description:
Ming Mang is a traditional game of Tibetan origin played on a NxN board.

The setup has all cells on the edges are occupied. The left and upper side by one player, the right and bottom side by the other. All pieces move like the rook in Chess. A piece is captured when it is between two enemy pieces - irrespective of the number of empty cells between the pieces. Captured pieces are converted to the color of the captor. Thus, although very unknown in Tibet, Othello (Reversi) pieces would work well.

When played on a 8 x 8 - board each player would start with fourteen men on the board and 14 in reserve to replace captured enemy pieces.

40574.name: Apit-Sodok
40574.description:
Apit-Sodok (Malaysia) or Mak-yek (Birma) is played on
a 8 by 8 board with sixteen pieces on each side. In the initial
setting pieces are covering the first and third row in front
of the player. Pieces move like the rook in Chess. Capturing
is both by interception (custodian capture) and intervention
(when a friendly piece is moved between two or more hostile
ones).

40575.name: Road Racer
40575.description:
[From the box back]

Start your engines in this high-rolling dice game that brings out the risky racer in all of us. Should you play it safe? Or risk it all with just one more roll? Pace your race to score 5000 miles as quickly as you can - but LOOK OUT! You could spin out nd lose it all. Beat the other racers past the finish line and head fr the winner's circle. Ready? Set? Roll!

Contents:
4 Custom Dice
1 Bonus Dice
Score Pad
Rules of Play

40576.name: Alpha Cards: The Game of Games
40576.description: This deck of 100 cards, each containing a letter and a point value except the two wild Alpha cards, can be used to play a variety of word games. Included with the game are instructions to play Alpha Cards and Team Alpha Cards (beginner and expert); Crazy Alpha, Alphataire, Five Card Alpha, and Five Letter Alpha.

40577.name: Der kleine U-Boot-Kommandant
40577.description:
The complete title including subtitle is "Der kleine U-Boot-Kommandant auf großer Fahrt nach Engelland" meaning "The little U-Boat-commander on his speed to England". This may be the first U-Boat game ever being published 1940 and certainly inspired by the previous successes (real and propagandistic) of the German submarine force.
Aim of the game is to shoot enemy vessels with a spring driven torpedo.

40578.name: M Squad
40578.description:
M Squad is a roll-and-move game featuring the famous TV-series of the late 50ies/early 60ies with male actor Lee Marvin starring and depicted on the box cover.

It's a light family game using the box inlay as game board.

You have to travel the town with small plastic cars in order to locate the daughter of a famous citizen who became a victim of a criminal act.

If you find some hints you can cover the name of the girl with small discs on the various locations.
The player who succeeds the first to cover the whole name with his discs is the winner of the game.

40579.description:
"Freibeuter der Karibik" is one of the first boardgame modules published for the YVIO game console.

The "Yvies" discs have to be inserted into pirate sailing ships, and you begin your mission to be the first player to gain 10 victory points (standard game).

Well-known ports like Cartagena or San Juan have to be visited to earn money in order to acquire equipment for your ships.
Every port requires two commodities and offers two others.
The longer the journey and the more valuable your cargo the larger your profit - but beware: What also becomes larger is the possibility to be attacked by rival pirates !
Some ports are the home of traders where you can buy equipment. These equipments not only give you victory points but also help your mission: Sails shorten your journey time and help to flee rivals, cannons help to fight them, sailors help in melee combat and larger trunks help to enlarge your profits.
And if you are too much playing for your own profit all the players loose if the rival pirates occupy at least 5 ports!
